OBITUARIES Information for the obituaries and funeral notices below was supplied to the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette Advertising Department by funeral homes.

INDEX Some obituaries may appear in certain editions of the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette and not in others. This list shows the names of all people whose obituaries are in at least one edition. For obituaries not in this edition, please see our website, Arkansas Online, at arkansasonline.com/obituaries/.

NATASHA S. AVERY, 32, Little Rock, departed this life May 6,2013. She leaves to cherish her memory: father, Gregory Avery; mother, Sherry Avery; siblings, Natalie Hubbard, Nekeya Ailsworth, Keith Avery, Deontay Roaf, Christie Allen, LaShawnda Brown, Stephanie, Danielle and Angela Avery; other family and friends.

Family hour: 6:45-7:45 p.m. Friday at Robinson Mortuary Chapel, LR. Funeral service: 11 a.m. Saturday at Antioch Full Gospel Baptist Church, 3824 Antioch Blvd., College Station. Services entrusted to Robinson Mortuary, 1201 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Drive, Little Rock (501) 371-0111. Sign online guestbook at www.robinsonmortuary.com “Service You Can Trust.”

———◊———

MARIE CROSS, age 86, of Jacksonville went to be with her Lord on Monday, May 6, 2013. She was born April 4, 1927, in Ranger, Ark., to the late John William and Amanda Leora Ashlin. She was a faithful member of First United MethodistChurch in Jacksonville for over 50 years and was very active in the Friendship Class and Mary Martha Circle. Mrs. Cross was a loving mother, grandmother and avid gardener. She was preceded in death by her husband, Charles E. Cross, and two sons, Charles Cross and Harold Cross.

She is survived by her son Tom Cross and his wife, Pat; one daughter, Laurie Staver, and her husband, Phil; one sister, Mary Larkin of Cabot; 11 grandchildren and 21 great-grandchildren.

Visitation will be from 6 p.m. until 8 p.m. on Wednesday, May 8, 2013, at Moore’s Jacksonville Funeral Home. Funeral services will be 11 a.m. Thursday, May 9, 2013, at First United Methodist Church in Jacksonville with Rev. Mark McDonald officiating. Interment will follow in Bayou Meto Cemetery.

In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to First United Methodist Church, 308 W. Main St., Jacksonville, Ark. 72076.

The Cross family would like to express their sincere appreciation to the staff of Woodland Hills Nursing Home for the care given to Mrs. Cross.

Arrangements by Moore’s Jacksonville Funeral Home & Crematory (501) 982-2136. Sign online guestbook at www.mooresjacksonvillefuneralhome.com.

———◊———

DARTHULIA HILL FRAZIER “Mrs. Doll” 76, of North Little Rock, Ark., made her heavenly transition May 2, 2013. She was born on Jan. 25, 1937, in England, Ark., to Lewis and Adline Hill.

She was a servant of God and she servedothers. She was a loving and devoted wife, mother and grandmother. She loved her family very much. She was a member of New Calvary Temple Church of God In Christ. She worked as a licensed practical nurse for 34 years at St. Vincent Infirmary.

She was preceded in death by her only sister, Louise Pierce.

Cherishing her memory are husband of 46 years, Daniel Frazier Sr.; one son, Daniel Frazier Jr.; two daughters, Sharon Frazier all of North Little Rock and Teresa Frazier of Duluth, Ga.; grandchildren, Shawn and Amari Harris of Duluth, Ga., Arial Frazier and Amber Welch of North Little Rock; a special brother-inlaw, Raliegh Pierce of Los Angeles, Calif.; a host of relatives and friends.

Special thanks to Arkansas Hospice, St. Vincent. Family hour May 10, 2013, 6-7 p.m. at Superior. Homegoing celebration May 11, 2013, 11 a.m. at New Calvary Temple Church Of God In Christ, 1120 Bishop Lindsey Ave., North Little Rock. Superior Funeral Services, 5017 E. Broadway, (501) 945-9922.

Online guestbook http://www.superiorfuneralservices.com/. Trudean Long Brown “Providing Services Your Family Deserves.”

———◊———

MARGARET ELLEN ROBINSON KEISER, age 101, passed awaySunday, May 5, 2013. She was born Nov. 14, 1911, in Chicago, Ill., to the late Frank Bennett Robinson and Alice Beree Robinson. She is preceded in death by her husband of 54years, Melvin (Pete) Keiser, who passed away in 1987.

She graduated in 1930 from Mishawaka High School and from nursing school at St. Joseph Hospital, Fort Wayne, Ind., in 1932. Margaret was a longtime member of the First United Methodist Church of Mishawaka, Ind.

She is survived by three children, Richard (Patricia) Keiser of Williamsburg, Va., Janet Hope Keiser and Barbara Jean Canfield of Little Rock, Ark.; four grandchildren, Eric (Jennifer) Keiser of Virginia Beach, Va., Todd (Melisa) Keiser of Indianapolis, Ind., Jason (Jennifer) Canfield of Fredericksburg, Va., and Stephen (Jodi) Canfield of Virginia Beach, Va.; seven great-grandchildren, Erica Keiser, Emily Keiser, Clay Keiser, Ryan Canfield, Mason Canfield, Dylan Canfield and Laurel Canfield.

The family would like to thank the doctors and nurses in the ICU Step-down, F-400 Hall at UAMS for the kind and professional care they gave Margaret.

Funeral services will be held in Mishawaka, Ind., at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to First United Methodist Church, 201 E. Third St., Mishawaka, Ind. 46544. Arrangements by Ruebel Funeral Home, www.ruebelfuneralhome.com.

———◊———

NORMAN KENNETH LIPKE, of Little Rock was called home tobe with the Lord on May 5, 2013, at the age of 74. Sandy, his loving wife of 25 years, was at his side.

Norman was born in Little Rock, Ark., on June 14, 1938. He is precededin death by his father and mother, Louis Fred and Dosha Lipke; his sisters, Joanne Lind and Bernice Meyers; his brothers, Don Lipke, Louis Lipke and Billy Rex Simpson.

Norman is lovingly remembered by his children, daughters: Tammy Lipke, Holly Hahn (Mark), Yvonne Hendrix (Doug), Robyne Ingram (Diane), Tracy Reece (Todd); sons: Michael Lipke, Gary Ingram and Eddie Lamb(Ashley); grandchildren: Stuart Lipke, Sam Lipke, Natalie Hahn, Nina Hahn, Kate Hendrix, Landon Parker, Emily Parker, Maisey Ingram, David Ingram, Alex Reece, Carson Lamb, Payton Lamb and Sawyer Lamb; also remembered by his brother, Kermit Bell.

The family would like to thank all of his doctors and all of the wonderful nurses at Hospice Home Care of Little Rock.

The funeral service will be held at Roller Drummond Funeral Home, 10900 Interstate 30, Little Rock, Ark. 72209 (501) 455-5800 on May 9 at 11 a.m. with Mark Blakley officiating. Burial to follow at Brown Cemetery, Barney, Ark., after the funeral service.

Pallbearers will be Brian Bottell, Norman Crook, Lester Harkins, David Hendrix and Landon Parker. Honorary pallbearers will be Doug Hendrix, Jerry Henthorn, C.W. Howell and Bill Weir.

Memorial donations may be made to American Cancer Society, 901 N. University Ave., Little Rock, Ark. 72207-6354. Online guestbook: www.rollerfuneralhomes.com/drummond.

CARL EDWARD MAXWELL, was born Dec. 11, 1960, and departedthis life May 3, 2013. He was a 1980 graduate of Little Rock Central and employed by Baptist Health for 28 years. He was preceded in death by his father, PastorW.C. Maxwell.

His memories will be cherished by his mother, Hertha L. Crutchfield-Maxwell; three sisters, Catherine Maxwell-Wimbley (Louis), Brenda Walker, Cynthia Maxwell-Thomas (Roderick); two brothers, Willie Maxwell (Sandra), Garry W. Maxwell (Shirley); special life partner, Regina Williams, and her daughters, Tanisha Williams and Renita Johnson; special pets, Chyna and Stormy; a host of loving nephews, nieces, aunts, uncles and friends.

Family hour: 5:30-6:30 p.m. Friday and funeral service: 11 a.m. Saturday, both to be held at Robinson Mortuary Chapel, LR. Services entrusted to Robinson Mortuary, 1201 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Drive, Little Rock (501) 371-0111. Sign online guestbook at www.robinsonmortuary.com “Service You Can Trust.”

TERRY LEE MYRICK, 46, of Jacksonville passed away peacefully at home on Monday, May 6, 2013. He worked as a civilian at the Little Rock Air Force Base for 25 years through Pathfinder, Inc. He enjoyed bowling and traveling with hisPathfinder family. He also was a member of First Baptist Church of Jacksonville.

He is survived by his mother, Grace Johnson of Jacksonville; his sister and brother-in-law, Tammy and David Avery of Sherwood; his brother and sisterin-law, Kent and Dee Myrick of Richton, Miss.; his nephew, Zachary Myrick of Jackson, Miss.; and his four nieces, Jessica Singleton and her husband, Stephen, of Jackson, Miss., Brynn McCollum and her husband, Kevin, of North Little Rock, Caitlin Myrick of Petal, Miss., and Kaylee Harvison of Sherwood.

Memorials may be made to Pathfinder, Inc. of Jacksonville.

Funeral services will be held at 2 p.m. on Thursday, May 9 at Griffin Leggett-Rest Hills Chapel. Burial will be in Rest Hills Memorial Park. The family will receive friends from 6 p.m. to 8 p.m. Wednesday at Griffin Leggett-Rest Hills, 7724 Landers Road, 835-3515. www.griffinleggettresthills.com.

———◊———

THOMAS “TOM” OLLIE, 87, of North Little Rock passed awaySaturday, May 4, 2013.

He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Margaret Ollie of North Little Rock; two sons, Thomas W. Ollie, Jr. and wife, Connie, of Swansea, Ill., and TimothyL. Ollie Sr. of Monticello; two daughters, Tamra L. Pianalto and husband, David, of Lowell, Ark., and Teresa L. Anderson of Little Rock; six grandchildren, Kasey, Samantha, T.J., Joe, Christy and Zach; five great-grandchildren, Reid, Ryland, Kaitlyn, Kylie and Elizabeth Claire; and a host of family and friends. He was preceded in death by his parents, Joe and Margaret Ollie.

Mr. Ollie’s accomplishments and service included the following. World War II veteran, Barrett Hamilton, Inc. 20 years sales representative and manager, where he received the Arkansas Marketing Award for Outstanding Salesman. Vice president United Dollar Stores. Owner of Tom Ollie School of Insurance, national vice president of United States Jaycees, first recipient of the Arkansas Clint Dunagan Award, JCI Senatorship Award, charter member of Riverside Rotary Club, 32nd Degree Mason, recipient of many rotary and civic organizational awards, song leader Triune Sunday School Class First United Methodist Church. The Jaycee “Tom Ollie Key Man Award” was named in honor of Mr. Ollie. 2013 will culminate 71 years of community service to his city, state and nation.

Funeral services will be held at 1 p.m., Thursday at First United Methodist Church. Burial will be in Roselawn Memorial Park.

Visitation will be from 5 to 7 p.m., Wednesday at North Little Rock Funeral Home, a Smith Family Funeral Home. Online obituary at www.SmithFamilyCares.com.

Perry; two sons, Percy Perry, III, Kinte Perry; one daughter, Wanda Gray; one special son, Rob Miller; one Godson, Kym Walls; three grandchildren; two great-grandchildren; six sisters; four brothers; a host of other relatives and friends.

JOHNNY LYLE POOLE, 65, of Little Rock, passed away May6, 2013. He was born in Shawnee, Okla., to James Willard Poole, Sr. and Mary Hanifan Poole, and was a U.S. Navy veteran.

He is survived by his children, daughter, Ginger Alexander (David); son, John Troy Poole; daughter, Lori Kirchner (Matt), all of Little Rock; and daughter, Sarah Turner (Andrew) of Navarre, Fla.; brother, James Poole, Jr. of Maryland; sisters, Janis Sperry (Tim) of Carson City, Nev., Barbara Follis (Dee) of Edmond, Okla., and Billie Kingham of Florida; and six grandchildren.

Visitation will be Thursday, May 9 from 6-8 p.m. at Little Rock Funeral Home, 8801 Knoedl Ct. (NW corner I-630 and Barrow Rd.). Walnut, Ste. 2309, Rogers, Ark. 72756.

Arrangements by Little Rock Funeral Home, (501) 224-2200. Johnny’s online guestbook may be signed at www.littlerockfuneralhome.com.

She was preceded in death by her husband, Willie Robieson; daughter, Shelia Robieson; parents, Lacy and Earrie Mae Gordan; brother, Arthur Gordon. She leaves tocherish her memory: children, Willetta (Bernard) Sampson, Fannie (Jan) Brazil, Stephanie (Charles) Green, Benita (Joseph) Proctor, Darrell (Joyce) Robieson; siblings, Perry (Gloria) Gordon, Lacy (Barbara) Gordon, Pinkie Gordon-Kelley, Dorthy Brown, Kathleen Keys, Melvin (Gloria) Grimes, Pervis Glosson; nine grandchildren; 16 great-grandchildren; one great-great grandchild; special caregivers, Erma Deadmon and Shelly Roberts; special thanks to Dr. Tommy Love and staff.

Perry of Laurens, New York; one grandson, Brett Matuszwski; one granddaughter Heather Weeks and her husband Bart; and one great-grandson Gavin Weeks.

She is survived by two sons, Vincent Settles and Keith (Victoria) Settles; one daughter, Elana Settles; nine grandchildren; five great-grandchildren; one niece, Brenda Daniels; three great-nieces; one great-nephew, Vincent (LaToya) Davie; and a host of other relatives and friends.

She is survived by two sons, Ronnie Taylor and Devon Taylor, four brothers, seven sisters, six grandchildren and a host of other relativesand friends. MARIJEAN OLIVER VOSS, 60, went to be with the Lord on Sunday, May 5, 2013. She was born to Martha McCrary Oliver and the late Earl L. Oliver Jr. Marijean attended Hall High and was a member of Kappa Kappa Gamma sorority at The University of Arkansas at Fayetteville.

She is survived by her husband, Mike Voss; son Doug Voss (Lee Ann); grandsons Mason and Preston Voss; mother MarthaMcCrary Oliver; mother-in-law Jean Montgomery Voss; sister Martha Lowe; nephew Mac Lowe (Shannon); niece Martha Huff (Clark); and a host of loving family and friends.

Marijean was a gentle and patient woman with a big heart. She was fiercely loyal to her family and friends. She always found time to listen, and she instinctively knew when someone needed a hug.

A graveside service will be held at 10 a.m. Friday, May 10 at Lonoke Cemetery followed by a celebration of Marijean’s life at 2 p.m. at FaithSpring Methodist Church, 501 S Bowman in Little Rock, next to Best Buy. Marijean loved flowers, no matter how simple or small. Arrangements by Roller-Chenal Funeral Home, 13801 Chenal Parkway, Little Rock, Ark., (501) 224-8300.

The family would like to thank the doctors and nurses of Baptist Medical Center for their exceptional care and attention.

Online guestbook at www.rollerfuneralhomes.com/chenal.

———◊———

THOMAS LEE (BUD) WALLS, 57, of Jacksonville was born Jan. 20, 1956,in Pocahontas, Ark., and went to be with Jesus on Friday, May 3, 2013. He was preceded in death by his father and mother, Leroy and Cona Walls of Jacksonville. Bud was a devoted father, grandfather, brother, uncle, cousin and friend to many.

He is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Ryan and Ashley Walls; two grandchildren, Diamond and Marshall Walls of Cabot; a stepdaughter, Paula Kay of Hot Springs; seven sisters; and one brother. He also is survived by many nieces, nephews, cousins, uncles, sister and brother-in-laws and numerous friends of various ages and backgrounds.

We thank God for the short time filled with so many memories that we all shared with Bud. Bud will be missed greatly by everyone who knew him, young and old alike.

A memorial service will be held at 2 p.m. Wednesday, May 8 at the Russell Chapel Church of the Nazarene, 30 Mahoney Road, Cabot, Ark. Please visit www.cremationsofarkansas.com to sign the online register.

———◊———

DALE WILLIAMS, 65, of North Little Rock died Friday, May 3, 2013. Dale was born Nov. 24, 1947, in Little Rock to the late JT and Emma (Newberry) Williams. He was also preceded in death by grandparents Arizona and James L. Williams, Maggie and Charlie McLaughlin and Hurbert Newberry; nephews John Sines Jr. and Jeff Sines; and nieces Zoey and Haley Sines.

Dale was in the Navy. He also welded at Babcocks in Alliance, Ohio. For the last 30 years, he has been a locksmith for Williams Lock & Key in North Little Rock. He was a very active member of the First Church of the Nazarene in Jacksonville. He loved his God. Dale is survived by his wife, Suzanne Williams of North Little Rock; daughter Rebecca Williams of Little Rock; sons Joe (Jody) Williams of Sherwood and Jason Allison of Ohio; grandchildren Sadie Schwires and Levi Allison of Ohio and Bruce Claiborn and Elisha Claiborn of North Little Rock; sister Beverly (Thomas) Ogden of North Little Rock; uncle Jack Williams of Jacksonville; great-nephew John Paul Corp; niece Kimberly Corp; great-nieces Tayia Corp of North Little Rock, Demilee Sines of Memphis and Danielle (Chris) Falcon of Baton Rouge, La.

Dale will be missed greatly by family and friends. He is with family and God now in Heaven. A memorial service will be held at 11 a.m. Saturday, May 11, 2013, at First Church of the Nazarene, Jacksonville. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the church. To sign his guestbook, please visit www.arkansasfuneralcare.com.

Arkansas

AUSTIN - Elsie Marie Eddy, 86, of Austin, died Tuesday, May 7, 2013. She was born October 24, 1926, in McCrory to the late Clarence and Etta Sims Taylor. Mrs. Eddy was a member of the First Pentecostal Church in North Little Rock. She loved her church and her family. She enjoyed music and taught her children to sing and play the guitar. In addition to her parents, Mrs. Eddy was preceded in death byher husband, Waymon Eddy; two sons, David and Rayburn Eddy; a grandson, Anthony LaFave; two brothers, Coy and Jessie Baker; and a sister, Mary Sue Baker.

Survivors areher children, Waymon Eddy, Jr. and his wife, Ione of Cabot, Paul Eddy and his wife, Barbara of Cabot, Darrell Eddy and his wife Peggy of Austin, Kenneth Eddy and his wife, Ruth Ann of North Little Rock, Juanita Brown and her husband, Edward of Cabot, Debi LaFave and her husband, Tom of Cabot, and Patricia Balentine and her husband, Lloyd of Cabot; two daughters-in-law, Gladys Eddy of Ward and Janice Eddy of Austin; one sister Wanda Moore of Indianapolis, Indiana; five brothers, Grady Taylor and James Taylor, both of Beebe, Estle Taylor of Austin, Jerry Baker of Heber Springs and Doyce Baker of Ingalls, Indiana; 39 grandchildren, 84 great grandchildren and two great-great grandchildren.

Visitation will be 6-8 p.m. Wednesday, May 8, 2013, in the chapel of Moore’s Cabot Funeral Home. Funeral services are 2 p.m. Thursday, May 9, 2013, at First Pentecostal Church in North Little Rock, with Rev. J.N. and Rev. Nathan Holmes officiating. Burial to follow at Mt. Carmel Cemetery in Cabot.

Arrangements are under the direction of Moore’s Cabot Funeral Home, (501)843-5816. Please sign the online guestbook at www.moorescabotfuneralhome.com.

BENTON - Maxine D. Lovell, age 90, of Benton, passed awayTuesday May 7, 2013, at Saline Memorial Hospice in Bryant, Arkansas. She was born in Dunkerton, Iowa, on September 1, 1922, to John William and Myrtle Henry Davis. Shewas preceded in death by her parents, her husband, Thaddeus M. Lovell, and her brother, Hugh Davis.

She is survived by her sons, Larry Lovell, of Memphis Tenn., and Scott (Pat) Lovell of Benton; grandchildren, Thad, Cord, Brandon (Jennifer), Matt and April, and two great-grandchildren. Her greatest love was her family.

Visitation will be from 6 to 8 p.m. Thursday at Ashby’s. Graveside services will be 1 p.m. Friday, May 10, 2013, at Pine Crest Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Saline Memorial Hospice Foundation, 23157 Hwy I-30 in Bryant, 72022.

CABOT - Carolyn Lavarne Barnes, 69, of Cabot, Ark .,passed away Sunday, May 5, 2013. She was preceded in death by her parents, Charlie and Arbeller Houston; brothers, Hershel Houston and Charlie Houston, Jr.; anddaughter, Brandy Barnes.

She’s survived by her husband, John Barnes; seven children, Bridgette Turner, John Barnes II, Regina Warren, Terrylyn Aaron, Joan Barnes, Jarod Barnes, and Natalie Barnes; one sister, Connie Houston-West; two brothers, Marvin Pillpot and Willbert Houston.

Viewing: Thursday, May 9, 2013, 3-6 p.m., and a celebration of her life will be Friday, May 10, 2013, 11 a.m., both services held at Ruffin and Jarrett Funeral Home Chapel, 1200 Chester Street, Little Rock, Arkansas (501) 372-1305.

———◊———

CABOT - Joe Owen, 83, of Cabot, passed away May 4, 2013. He was born in England, Arkansas, to Isaac and Cecil (Toler) Owen on October 7, 1929. He is preceded in death by his parents and brother, Julius Owen.

He is survived by his sister, Barbara Garza, daughter Tanya Owen (Matt Floyd), special friends Pat and Butch Barker, and a host of nieces and nephews.

In high school, Joe held the Arkansas state record in the 880 in Track and Field for many years and was also Cabot High School’s first quarterback. After graduation, he enlisted in the Army and served a tour in Korea. He received a Bachelor of Science degree in Education and returned to Cabot High School as a football coach and a teacher. He loved horse racing, football and visiting his best friends at the beach, “pretty horses and fast women”, as he liked to put it! He was a huge Sinatra fan and as his favorite song said, he truly did ithis way. No regrets. He lived a simple life with a large dose of happiness.

A memorial service will be held May 8, 2013 at 12 p.m. at the Arkansas State Veteran’s Cemetery, 1501 W. Maryland Ave, North Little Rock.

In lieu of flowers, memorials should be made to Arkansas Hospice Foundation, www.arhospice.org. Please share a memoir by visiting the online guest book at www.arkansasfuneralcare.com. Arrangements made by Arkansas Funeral Care.

COVE - Mr. Richard Gilbert, age 74, of Cove, Arkansas, passed away Sunday, May 5, 2013, in Mena. Funeral services will be Thursday, May 9, 2013, at 2 p.m. at the Cove First Baptist Church. Interment will follow in Pinecrest Memorial Gardens under the direction of the Beasley-Wood Funeral Home.

———◊———

COY - Zelma Mae Johnson, 93, of Coy, Arkansas belovedMother, Grandmother, and Great-Grandmother, entered her heavenly home May 6th, 2013. She was born February 14th, 1920. Throughout her life Zelma maintained a sweetand simple demeanor and unwavering faith in God as did her beloved husband of fifty-seven years, Turner C. Johnson who preceded her in death on January 2nd, 1998. They devoted their careers to agriculture while locating in Coy, Arkansas. Sheenjoyed cooking for her loved ones and was especially known for her cinnamon rolls, Mexican cheese dip, and the best peanut brittle, pickles and Christmas candy. She met hard work head-on and was always faithful in her support of her husband, family and church.

Zelma’s adult life can be summed up as a faithful wife, mother, grandmother, and one who loved our Lord Jesus Christ above all things. She passed on to her family her unwavering love for the Lord so that they may all together be rewarded by Him-as even today, she hears the Words of Him who keeps her close, “Now there is in store for you the crown of righteousness…”

Zelma was preceded in death by her parents: Tom and Sarah Haley; her brothers: Seibert, Loy, Eldon, Sandy, Tom, and Faye Haley; one sister: Ruby Tabor; two grandchildren: Rachel and Rebecca Cicero.

FAYETTEVILLE - Gail Ferguson Martens Stoops died peacefullyon May 6, 2013, surrounded by her loving family and friends. Gail was born March 2, 1936, in New London, Texas, to Irene and Fred Ferguson. She attended Baylor University.

Her early life included a marriage to Jim Martens and working as a child welfare officer in Baton Rouge, La. She also used her training at Baylor University to begin writing professionally. She wrote for Louisiana’s Conservationist and Wildlife and Fisheries magazines, collecting wild game recipes from Louisiana’s most prominent chefs.

During her career at NASA, she was the director of public relations for the Apollo Moon Missions. She was friends with early astronauts Neil Armstrong and John Glenn. She then married Gordon Stoops, who worked with Wernher von Braun as head of rocket propulsion development for the Saturn rockets. It was during these years that Gail and Gordon frequently entertained Russian cosmonauts in their legendary Texas Gulf Coast style.

After the death of her sons, Greg and Danny, Gail devoted her life to art. She became an international artist, with her works bringing joy across the continents. As powerful as her paintings are, her impact in the studio is even greater. She was a mentor, surrogate mother and unwavering friend to hundreds of students, many of whom became professional artists and teachers of art themselves. The evidence of her influence was apparent in the constant expression of gratitude and love during the hours before her death.

She is preceded in death by her parents; husbands Jim Martens and Gordon Stoops, two sons, Greg and Danny Martens, as well as her brother Don Ferguson.

She is survived by her son, James F. Martens and his wife, Jette, of Austin, Texas; and daughter, Marianna Hendrycy and her husband, Paul, of Fayetteville, Ark. She is also survived by Cloace McGill and her husband, Henry, and their three daughters. Also surviving are her grandchildren, Jessica Reddick, Dana Craw, Robin Martens, Gordon Martens, Paul Goerlitz, Katy Martens and Max Hendrycy.

Gail will be buried alongside her sons, Greg and Danny, in Streetman, Texas, on May 18, 2013. A memorial service will be held in Fayetteville at a later date. To sign the online guest book, please visit www.nelsonberna.com.

WHITE HALL - Tilden Oney Bridges, 303 Cooper Street, White Hall, Ark., died at Jefferson Regional Medical Center (JRMC) in Pine Bluff, Ark., on May 6, 2013. He was born on September 9, 1922 in Pine Bluff, Ark., andspent the majority of his life in White Hall. Parents were BennieRichard Oney Bridges and Hattie Lee Honey Bridges. He was married to Minnie Ola Wolf Bridges on April 4, 1945 and celebrated 68 years together this past April.

Tilden graduated from White Hall High School in 1941 and immediately began his long career with Arkansas Power and Light Company. In November of 1942, he enlisted in the United States Air Force and in January of 1946, he went back to work for AP&L (now known as Entergy) until his retirement in March of 1985. He was a Senior Cable Splicer and as such played a major role in the installation and maintenance of the underground cable operation in Little Rock, Pine Bluff and towns south of Pine Bluff.

Tilden and Minnie have been active members of Central Baptist Church on Dollarway Road since 1957. Before and after retirement, they traveled, pulling an Airstream travel trailer for 36 years. Dad served as President of the Arkansas Razorback Airstream Travel Club at one time, and was always an active member for the Club attending many International and Regional Rallies. He was also a member of International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) for 60 years. Tilden was President of Pine Bluff’s Entergy Retirees’ Club as well as being chosen to represent the group on the Steering Committee for Retirees of Entergy at a state level. He was also an active member in his church’s senior citizens group (SAM’s Club).

Tilden’s 90th birthday last September was celebrated with a proclamation from the Mayor of White Hall, proclaiming it Tilden Oney Bridges Day in White Hall. Mayor Foster presented him with the award at a party held in City Hall.

In addition to his wife, he is survived by one daughter, Linda Gayle Brown and friend Leigh Cole of Roland, Ark.; one grandson, Kuhl Brown, III and Amy Boom of Denver, Colo. He is also survived by several nieces and nephews.

Tilden was preceded in death by his parents and sister, Francis McWilliams; four brothers, Harris (Bud) Bridges, Coy Bridges, Roy Bridges, and Joe Bridges.

Visitation with the family will be Thursday, May 9, at Ralph Robinson & Son Funeral Home, Cherry St. at 8th Avenue in Pine Bluff, Ark., from 6-8 p.m.

Funeral Services will be held at Central Baptist Church, 6107 Dollarway Road, White Hall, at 10 a.m. on Friday, May 10. Burial will be at White Hall Methodist Church Cemetery in White Hall, Ark. Online Register:www.ralphrobinsonandson.com.
